Award.AwardTitle: PBI: A Complete Web-based Monograph of the Tribe Miconieae (Melastomataceae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
A collaborative effort led by scientists from The New York Botanical Garden, the University of Florida, the Universidade Federal de Paran√°, and the California Academy of Sciences, along with several collaborators in the US, Latin America and Europe, will produce a complete taxonomic inventory and monographic description of the tribe Miconieae in the plant family Melastomataceae. Melastomataceae is a group of over 1800 species from the Americas, mostly trees and shrubs from tropical rain and montane forests. These plants are ecologically important due to their diversity and abundance in forest understories, and because they are an important food source for tropical birds and mammals. The Miconieae also include two of the worst plant invasives in the Hawaii and South Pacific Islands (Koster's curse [Clidemia hirta] and purple plague [Miconia calvescens]), and the distributional changes of these invasives will be documented. The project will comprehensively review all of the 1,800 species, combining studies in the field, herbarium, and laboratory to produce a thorough taxonomic inventory and phylogenetic analysis of the group.

All of the information generated by the study will be available online through a dedicated module of NYBG's botanical database, the Virtual Herbarium. The database will include complete description and images for all species, keys for their identification, and distribution maps for each species. The project will train postdoctoral associates and graduate students in the US and Latin America on the tools of modern monographic treatments and taxonomic nomenclature. Local scientists will be integral part of the field work and will also be trained, and an intensive course for Latin American students and scientists on the systematics and taxonomy of the Melastomataceae will take place during the third year of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The tribe Miconieae (Melastomataceae) with almost 1900 species is an exclusively Neotropical group distributed from the Antilles, throughout Central Mexico and Central America to Northern Argentina and found in all humid environments from sea level to 4000 m. Most of the species are shrubs and small trees, but some species can be herbs, lianas or large trees.  This group also includes two of the most notable weeds in Hawaii and other Pacific islands belong to this group: Koster’s curse (Miconia crenata = Clidemia hirta) and velvet tree (Miconia calvescens). In spite of its size and ecological importance, the family has not received the same level of attention in phylogenetic and monographic studies as other groups of comparable size.  The last comprehensive monograph of the tribe (and the family) dates back to 1891 when less than half of the currently recognized species had been described. In order to study this ecologically important and diverse group, we built a large collaborative team of researchers, postdocs, students and collaborators in the US and throughout Latin America. The main objective of the project was to increase or knowledge of this understudied clade by collecting in poorly sampled areas, carrying out herbarium studies, producing a tribe level phylogeny and by producing monographs for selected groups as these were studied in detail. 

PBI-Miconieae researchers, postdocs, students and collaborators carried out field work in 26 countries, collecting over 8000 specimens of Melastomataceae. This resulted if the description of 111 new species of Melastomataceae, with an additional 50 now in preparation.  Phylogenetic studies have greatly helped our understanding of which genera of berry-fruited Melastomataceae belong to the tribe and the relationships among its species. These phylogenetic studies have also contributed to our understanding of the biogeography of tropical forests and morphological character evolution.  These results have also been pivotal on the taxonomic reorganization of the tribe in a single genus Miconia.

The PBI-Miconieae also had in significant impact in training the next generation of modern plant systematists.  Five different postdocs, nine Ph. D. students, four Master of Science students, seven undergraduates and one high school student were actively trained by the project.  Additionally, project personnel taught courses on Melastomataceae identification or Melastomataceae systematics in evolution in Colombia (three courses) and Brazil (four courses), with smaller one day workshops in Peru and Cuba.  Moreover, many of the staff hired as research assistants during the project have gone on to graduate school or now how permanent positions in collections management. Results of the project have been made publicly available (http://sweetgum.nybg.org/melastomataceae), and nomenclatural and taxonomic updates are constantly updated (http://melastomataceae.net).
